div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria weekly..as under for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Oriental Railways Express Service for Vienna, Berlin, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Saturday at 4 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUTH (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MERSINA, calling fortnightly at LARNACA (Cyprus) and continuing from Beyrout in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardahelles, Gallipoli anf Constantinople.
The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suez alternately on Wednesdays at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sedan Government Railways express service to Khartoum.

Mail Steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sina), Yambo and Jeddah, continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah and Aden. For further information refer to the Co.'s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Fort Said, Suez or to THOS. COOK and SON (Eygypt) Ltd., HAMBURG-AMERIEA REISE-BUREAU or other Tourist Agencies.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: RELIGIOUS STAGNATION AT HOME.
div.p: The religions Press and men who see the signs of the times are rather despondent just now with regard to the stagnation of the Churches in England. Recently the "Christian World" declared that "the Churches, as at present organised, are in a backwater. Meantime the tide of the national life rolls irresistibly forward. The question for our religious leaders is as to how far their teaching and method coincide with that movement, or is opposed to it. The future of the Churches depends on the way that question is answered."

Referring to Mr. Meyer's recital to the Baptist Union of the experiences gained daring his recent tour amongst the churches of the denominatioD, the same paper says it "was of a somewhat mixed description. It was as full of lights and shadows as an April day. On ths whole, the shadows seemed to predominate. The lack amongst them of commanding personalities such as were seen in the last generation, the waste of energy involved in oreating snch multitudes of small and limited spheres, the pressure of poverty in the chnrches, and the disturbing theological tendencies of the time, were amongst the conditions he noted. They cannot, indeed, escape the attention of any observant mind .

"Another fact that, in this oategory, be failed to notice, Beems to us one of the most ominons of all. It is that in a plaos lila> London the whole combined energy of the Baptist chnrches in the Union has resulted in an increase of no more than 200 members. If this, however, be a symptom, it is one that is shared, apparently, by all^the religious bodies. Methodism, with all its costly central missions, has made no advaooe daring the year."Then the "British Weekly," dealing with the Wesleyan Methodist census taken by the "Methodist Recorder," which announces this year a slight decrease, says; — "The decreases are: Full members, 1982; on trial, 6152; junior members, 1989—or, in all, 10,123 fewer names on the class books than twelve months ago. It will be remembered that this decrease follows on large increases, and in all probability it represents the usual reaction from a revival. None the less, it is a grave fact, to be seriously weighed."The "Methodist Times" says : — "It is perhaps not altogether surprising that this year's figures show signs of some reaction. We desire neither to minimise nor to exaggerate their significance. They call for very serious attention. Whatever standpoint be adopted they represent a resnlt incommensurate with the agencies of the Church. When we remember the immense organisations represented by our Sunday-schools, Guilds, Brotherhoods, and the like we ought to receive a Urge and steady increase year by year. Moreover, we ought not only to keep pace with the growth of the popuUtion, but to make great advances in the effective evangelisation of the nation."The English Presbyterian Church reports a membership of 85,775, an increase of only 540, as against an annual average increase of 1558 during the last ten years.The "Christian Commonwealth"declaiw that " The dearth of candidates for ordination in the Church of England, the unsatisfactory calibre of the young men who enter the Nonconformist ministry, the small number of preachers of the Gospel who have a spiritual (not a merely political or social) message that arrests attention, the general decline in attendance at religious worship, to which may be added the high mortality among religious newspapers in both hemispheres in recent years, are a few of many indications of the fact that organised Christianity has for some time past been steadily loeing its hold npon the thinking portion of the nation. Is it not time that Christian preachers took stock of their position, and ascertained precisely where they stand, what they believe, and what they have to offer 1 "The Established Church, says the "Christian World," according to its published returns, has actually gone backward. At a ruridecanal conference at Chulmleigh, and reported by the "Standard," Achdeacon Seymour referred with regret to the fact that chnreh attendance in rural districts was becoming slack, owing to the shortage of Ubour on the farms. Farmers were not able to get as many men as they nsed to years ago, and the result was that they hod to do more work themselves on a Sunday. Mr. Cole, a farmer, said things were rather worse than this. The Ubonrers would not work on Sundays, and it thus became impossible for the farmers to attend church more than once on the Sabbath. This rather suggests the story of the cabman who, when asked by a lady whom he had just pnt down at the church door " How do you spend your Sundays 1 " replied—" Driving the likes of yon to church."The Bishop of Stepney sees the need of action. At the London Diocesan Conference a few weeks ago he said:— "Whatever else the last general election showed, it made clear, for weal or woe, that the springs of public life were to be found for the future not in readers of the "Times", but in those of the "Clarion", the vast masses of our working classes, so seldon'heard in such assemblies as this. Not much could be done in helping on the great moral and social questions of the day by sermons or legislation. They wanted a new idea of Church life and corporate responsibility. They must translate into concrete fact in every parish what they had taught in the pulpit They talked much of the rights of the laity, but too few hod an idea of rendering active service in the Church of their baptism. They had thought too much of machinery and too little of the men it was to influence. They wanted the creation of a Demos of the Church. They must appeal to the average manhood of the Church and seek their active service. That was the object of the Church of England Men's Society."Mr. Bernard Shaw is also among the prophets of gloom. Speaking to members of the National Art Collections Fund, in the rooms of the Society of Antiquaries, he declared that "there was, he thought, more general recognition than there had been at almost any time in onr history of the fact that art was really almost the only means of teaching the people. It was becoming conspicuous that the Churches were loeing their hold very largely on congregations, and that the theatre was beginning to compete with them. The aid of art would have to be obtained if the people were to be brought back to the Churches. It was through art that we were going to keep up the really great traditions which alone ooald constitute a really permanent and stable society."

div.head: San Stefano Casino.
div.p: There is shortly to be a children's fete at San Stefano casino, on which occasion prizes wfii Ac awarded to the best burlesques. The fete is specially intended for children under 8 years of age, of families who are subscribers to the casino. On Sunday morning the Bracale orchestra will give a classical concert, the programme of which will include the overture from Wagner's "Maltres Chanteurs." To-morrow afternoon at five o'clock there will be a children's ball directed by Mr. Longhi.

div.head: The Tebtunls Papyri.
div.p: The second part of the "Tebtunis Papyri," edited by Dr. B. P. Grenfell and Dr. A. S. Hunt, with the assistance of Prof. E J. Goodspeed, of Chicago, will be published by Mr. Henry Frowde early next month. It deals with papyri found in the houses of Tebtunis, most of the documents belonging to the first three centuries of the Christian era. An important literary fragment is that of the lost Greek original of Dictys Cretensis.

div.head: Agricultural Labour In the Sudan.
div.p: The Sudan Government has issued an order to the effect that landowners and others may further obtain special terms for the transport over Sudan Government Railways between Haifa and Khartoum North for parties composed of not less than fifty adult persons who (jdfe being brought into the Sudan as agriccMnral labourers. Information regarding thestf&pecial terms he obtained horn the Director of Railways to whom all applica- tiqjg for this privilege should be addressed. We do not definitely know what there special terms are. But we understand that they are very liberal, and it is hoped that they will be a boon to landowners, and others interested in the agricultural development of the Sudan.

div.head: POSITION OF FOREIGN DIRECTORS.
div.p: What is the exact position of a Director of an English Company, who is not a British subject, but who has erred against the statutory regulations of English Company Law 1 This is a question that has recently been asked by many shareholders in English companies in Egypt, and it is one which it is considerably easier to ask than to answer.

For example according to English law, a Board of Directors who have authorised the payment of a dividend out of Capital, are personally liable to refund such money to the Company out of their own pockets, and can be compelled by action in the Courts to do so. But suppose this board is composed of two Englishmen and three members who do not ordinarily fall under the British jurisdiction. The Englishmen can undoubtedly be attacked in the English (that is the Consular) Court and will be dealt with there according to English law. But what of their three confreres who have been equally guilty 1 Can they too be summoned and compelled to pay by the British Consul. With the Capitulations still in force such proceedings might give rise to international complications and were the proceedings, as they quite easily might be, of a criminal nature, under the present regime no British Court would have the right to sit in judgment on any save a British subject. The plaintiff or prosecutor, as the case might be, would of course be of British nationality since it would be the company suing in its corporate capacity : and according to the ordinary observances civil suits between people of mixed nationality come before the Mixed Tribunals.
What law then would the Mixed Tribunals apply to the contravention of English Statute law.

In the Code, by which proceedings in- the Mixed Tribunal are or should be regulated, naturally none of the complicated rules of the English Company Laws find a place but in Article 11 of the Civil Code occurs the following passage. "Where the law is silent insufi- cient or obscure the judge shall follow the principles of natural right and the rules of equity." Now it might easily be contended by the layman at least that at first sight the English Company law does not appear to be a law of natural right or a rule of equity, that is as understood in the French meaning of the word.

But on the other hand it might well be argued that the Directors have signed the prospectus in accordance with English law, and have done other acts shewing their willingness to comply with English regulations and in-so doing have held themselves out to have some knowledge of its broader principles. In short should the British Consul refuse to legislate in a case of the sort supposed, and should the matter be brought before the Mixed Tribunals the only reasonable legislation for the Tribunals to adopt appears to be that which the Directors viitually chose for themselves by forming their Company under the "aegis" of English Law.

It seems in no way "a natural right or a rule of equity" that a man should obtain all the benefit of such law and at the same time by a local technicality be enabled to rid himself of all his obligations thereunder.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: Early next week the Khedive will terminate his visit to Constantinople, and go to Kissin- gen, where he will remain six or eight weeks. Before returning to Egypt his Highness will spend another week at Constantinople. According to Reuter's telegram, the Khedive paid a visit yesterday to Sir Nicolas O'Connor, English Ambassador.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY.
div.p: EXTRAORDINARY POLICY.

It is to be hoped that the Ministry of the Interior will scrutinise the very curious proceeding at yesterday's meeting of the Alexandria Municipal Commission. The Municipality recently gained a law suit in reference to a claims to some land at Chatby. Yesterday on the proposition of Padoa Bey the commission voted that three thousand pies of land at Chatby should be given to Osman Bey, an official of the Municipality, director of the Tar.zim Service at Alexandria, as a' reward for his services in the law suit. This gift represents a cash value of about £15,000. The land thus given away is public property and is situated at Chatby. Such an extraordinary system of granting away the property of the city to officials of the Municipality solely on the ground that the recipient did his duty deserves to be noted. It should form a very useful precedent for similar grants of public property to the fortunate officials of the Municipality.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. "Imperial Prince," with passengers and general cargo left London on the 2nd inst, and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 19th inst
The S.S. "Kaffir Prince," with passengers and general cargo, left Manchester on the 1st. inst., and is due to arrive at this port on or about the 16th. July.
The S S. "Roman Prince" with passengers and general cargo left Malta on the 2nd. inst., and is due to arrive at Alexandria on Saturday the 6th. July.

div.head: ANNUAL SPORTS.
div.p: The annual sports of St. Catherine's College have now become one of the popular sporting events of the year, and are not only looked forward to with keen interest and pleasure by the hundreds of youths of all nationalities who reap the benefit of healthful exercise and sound education, so thoroughly well blended in this excellent institution, but by a very large section of our cosmopolitan city, who are fortunate enough to obtain invitation for the occasion.

Elaborate arrangements were made to ensure the success of yesterday's "fete des jeux," and over three thousand spectators were comfortably seated in the spacious playground on which special stands were erected for their accommodation. The ground and stands were gaily decorated with garlands and flags.

At 4.0 p.m. M. Pierre Girard, Consul General of France, arrived, and the proceedings commenced with the march past. As the long procession of some six hundred boys, smartly dressed in blue jerseys, white knickers, and red sashes, made their appearance headed by the band of the college, and the French and Egyptian flags, a hum of admiration and then a burst of applanse arose from the crowded arena Surely Alexandria might well feel proud of such a display of youthful vigour.

The various events were, as usual, an unqualified success, and Mr. Arthur Elmas, the gymnastic instructor of the college, is to be heartily complimented on having brought the boys to such a high standard of perfection. The "mouvements d'ensemble" are worthy of more than passing notice. Mr. Elmas has his pupils well in hand, and their excellent performance of the several interesting drills produced enthusiastic applause.

The performances on the horizontal bars and on the parallels showed a great improvement on last year, the triple bar exercises being particularly good, thanks again to Mr. Elmas. The boys conspicuous in gymnastics were O. Giuliotti, C. Malak, L. Barbaza, Z. Simaiker and N. Galioringhi. Unfortunately young Giuliotti was not in his best form yesterday, but he has the making of a first class athlete : his work on the horizontal bar is far beyond that of the average boy amateur. Excellent work was also done by Malak, Barbaza and Sirmaiker.
The following are the results of the principal
events.
Gymnastics 1st section : — Gold medal— Louis Barbaza ; Silver gilt medal -1- Charles Malak ; Silver medal—Oswald Giuliotti.
A special prize of a gold watch for the best all-round competitor presented by Mr. A. Campos was won by 0. Giuliotti.
Gymnastics 2nd section Silver medal— Lazare Bissara; Bronze medal—Albert Lanzetta
Course aux attelages—R. Mifsud and T. Tifinek
Course de vitesse (small boys)—S. Nuccari ; (Juniors)—A. Fitte ; (Seniors)—C. Corbetes.
Hurdle race—J. Scalfarotto and C.Verdellis.
Course de fond—C. Frangoulis.
Stilt race (Juniors) — G Scalfarotto; (Seniors) —C. Malak.
A special prize for constant application throughout the year was presented by Mr. Elmas to N. Galiounghi.

The jury was composed of the following gentlemen, all old boys of the college : Messrs. Alfred Campos, Leopold Jullien, Ariel Goldstein Bey, Ambroise Laverdo, Antoine Sayour, A. Yelkendjoglou and George Zananiri Bey.

A word of praise is due to the college band whose excellent performance during the afternoon assisted in making it one of the most successful ever held in the college. We tender our congratulations to the good brothers and anticipate something even better, if possible, next year.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: The Council of Ministers met on Tuesday afternoon at San Stefano under the presidency of H.E. The Regent. The following decisions were made:
To fix a definite tax on lands on which no tax has yet been fixed.
To grant for public use the land necessary for the widening of Shareh-el-Midan at Alexandria.
To grant for public use the land necessary for the roads on the El-Kalaktarieh laud at Alexandria.
To grant for. publio use, the completion of the Rue Abbas at Mansourah.
To grant, for public use four deviations of the Nile in the Moudirieh of Dakhlieh.
To appoint Mr. Clifton to act as under secretary of state for towns and buildings until the return of Mr. Richmond.
To allow the concession to the Cairo Water Company to extend to Rodah Island.
To approve five proposals of the minister of Education :—
Change of the curiculum for secondary education and the modification of Artiole 35 of the Code of organisation and discipline of schools.
Regulations concerning the scholarships in secondary schools.
Modification of Articles 66 and 100 of the Code of organisation and discipline of schools.
Modification of the programme in secondary schools.

To allow the Cairo Eleotric Railways and Heliopolis Oasis Company to occupy a quarter instead of a sixth of the land ceded by the government on condition that 400 houses are reserved for government officials.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Sirdar, Six Reginald Wingate, and Slatin Pasha were present at the King's leave on Tuesday week.
Lowa Assa Pasha, Acting Sirdar and Governor General of the Sudan, has arrived in Cairo from Khartoum and is proceeding to Europe on leave.

Among other passengers who arrived by the last Sudan express in Cairo we note the names of Mir. Sir H. B. Hill, Barto Bey, Mir. Dickinson Bey, Capt. Kennedy, Bimb. McLfied, Bimb. Huskisson, Bimb. Moore, Bimb. Hadow, Mr. Rhodes, Yuzb. Nessib Abcarius and Mrs. Abcarius, Mr. Wilkinson, Mr. Merton, Mr. Sharp, Mr. Langridge and Count Niraki.
Major-General Sir Rudolph Slatin Pasha is now in London and staying for the season at his chambers, 29, St. James'BStreet.
Mouheb Pasha, Governor General of the Sues Canal, is in London for some little time, staying at the Diendonn£ Hotel, in Ryderstreet, St. James's.

The report, to which publicity was given by a Cairo newspaper, is denied that Saba Pasha the retiring Postmaster-General, is proposing bis candidature for the Governorship of the Lebanon, vacant by the death of Muzaffer Pasha.
De Martino Pasha, Director-General of the Daira Khassa, and Mme de Martino left on Saturday for Europe. The Pasha will rejoin the Khedive at Vienna on Jnly 14.
Mr. F. de Szarvazy, Austrian Vice-Consul at Alexandria, has been appointed Consul at Cairo, replacing Mr. Hann de Hannenheim.
By order of the Ministry of the Interior two months leave has been granted to M. Boniteau Bey, Director of the European Office.
Mr. Huge Beadnell, Oasis Manager of the Corporation of Western Egypt, is going to England on three months leave, and leaves Port Said by the P. & 0. S.8. "Bfitannia" on the 9th inst.

The marriage took place at St Bartholomew's, Burwash, on Wednesday week of Mr. Charles Albert Haselton Aldersou, second son of Mr. George B. Alderson, Alexandria, and Miss Mabel Rubie Harden, eldest daughter of Mr. T. R Harden, of Burwash. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles F. Maude.

Mr. William Jackson Maltass, whose valse "Happy Memories" was recently played with such success at the Windsor Hotel, Alexandria, is engaged on the composition of an opera. Mr. Maltass left Alexandria yesterday for Constantinople by the Khedivial Company's S.S. "Osmanieh," where he intends to spend the summer.

div.p: The Turkish Government has chartered a vessel from the Khedivial Mail Steamship Co. Ltd. for the transport of troops to and from the Yemen. It is said that the forces of General Faizi Pasha are to be strengthened by 10,000 troops.

L'acuite et l'imprlvu de la crise financihre qui s'est abattue sur l'Egypte devaient fored ment imprtSgner nos publioistes de la n&essiW de dlgager et de pr&iser le sens des meaures propres 5 remldier 5 la crise ou writer son retour 5 l'avenir.

Vous avez vite fait de montrer dans l'un de vos demiers numd-ros ce qu'avait d'ilfrgale, de trompeuse et de malsaine, la dernihre proposition de ce genre sngg4r4e par un de vos confrere d'Alexandria et qui a vite fait d'accueiUir 1'approbation ou les suffrages de nos publicistes s'occupant de finance. On ne sait vraiment qu'admirer le plus de l'extravagance crimi- nelle que rechlent de pareilles meaures si elles 5taient appliqu&a ou de l'ing4nuite et de l'in- conscience avec lesquelles elles sont accueiliies ou propag&s. On ne saurait faire 4 mon avis de plus grand mal 4 la place dans le marasme oh elle se ddbat actuellement, qu'en faisant luire ou miroiter 5 ses yeux ces sortes d'erreurs comme les panaches souveraines devant procurer les remhdea infaillibles 5 la situation.

On a d'abord commence par agiter la question de la transformation de la National Bank en Banque d'Etak Cette transformation eat une belle chose. Mais il s'agit de savoir quel est le but 4 poursuivre. Si je ne me trompe, il s'agit d'assurer 4 l'Egypte une circulation mon4taire indlpendante et stable et une somme de numeraire propre qui soit hors de portee ou de la fluctuation des places ytranghres, quelles que soient les circonstances s4vissant sur ces places on la nfltre.

Il suffira de remarquer d'abord que si la circulation mon4taire a ety raise 5 une rude ypreuve, si elle a subi une trhs forte contraction, contraction incontestable, du fait du dy- faut de l'argent fibre snr la place, le numeraire employ^ ou 4 l'usage de l'Egypte n'a pas snivi Ini, un pareil declin, detenu qu'il est en grande partie dans les coffres des banques. La question en r&ditl est plus haute et se ramhne 5 celle-ci, savoir, qui aura le contrble de l'argent de la Banque et de son emploi 1 Sera-ce l'Egypte ou PE u rope 1 Oq qui dit possession dit contrble et qui dit contrdle dit liberty d'agir. Et comme l'on sait perti- nemment que la pins grande paitie du capital de la National Bank a iti foumie par l'Europe, ou plus exactement par les capitalistes anglais, le contrdle de l'emploi dee capitanx de la Banque fchappera forclment 5 l'Egypte taut que celle-ci nesera pas kmdme de s'en rendre possesseur. Car on ne s'imagine pas les capitalistes anglais acceptant par allhche- ment pour le profit, de r£server l'emploi exclusif de cet argent pour l'Egypte, ou qui plus est, acceptant de le maintenir en circulation sans souci de la situation ftnan- cihre ou commerciale de la place. Us n'abdi- queraient pas leur liberty d'agir du simple fait de la transformation de la National Bank en Banque d'Etat. A la rigueur on pourrait leur imposer de ne pas exporter cet argent qui forme le capital de le#Banque s'ils ne trouvent pas desirable ou opportun pour eux de l'employer 5 mV moment donmS sur la place. Mais quel statut, rhglement on arrgtd serait capable de leur imposer ou de d£cr4ter l'emploi forc4 de cet argent sans contrflle ou liberty absolue de leur park Les Egyptians eux-mfimes ne risqueraient pas leur argent dans une entreprise 4 qui pareil sort serait r4serv4 et Ton voudrait que des capitalistes gangers se mettent aux ordres de l'Egypte. Se figure-ton la Banque d'Etat du Maroc se mettant 4 la re morque de la place marocaine au lieu de suivre le mot d'ordre des places europdennes] la Banque d'Etat, je le r<-p5te, ne serait possible telle qu'on la reve ou 4 pen prhs,—- car il reste 5 voir si le sens de solidarity des aotion- naires de cette Banque avec les intyrtts de la place les poussera 5 dyerhter l'emploi continu de leur argent quelles que soient les conditions pryvalant 5 l'intyrieur ou 4 l'extyrieur du pays,—que si l'argent qui forme le capital de la Banque est en majeure partie contrfiiy par l'Egypte. L'acheminement vers la solution du problhme ryside done dans l'afflnence ou l'importance de la participation des capitaux tigyptiens appartenant en propre 4 l'Egypte dans nos institutions financihres ou toutes celles qui se donnent pour objet le dyveloppe- ment et l'exploitation du pays Tel devrait etre le sens dans lequel nos publicistes financiers devraient travailler.

Venons-en maintenent 5 la dernihre panacye qui a yty agitye, l'ymission des banque-uotes avec r4serves incomplhtes garanties par l'Etat sur ses biens fibres. Comment, la base de la Bank-Note, on le sait bien, est la confianoe et l'assurance qu'a le porteur de savoir que son argent est sous bonne garde et qu'il est realisable sur-le-champ, et Ton va mettre 5 la place des terrains inafi5nables dont l'effet serait dysastrenx en cas d'un '.'run" et oh le gouvente- ment n'aurait d'autre ressource que de les rembourser sur'sa propre reserve 1 Quelle serait d'ailleurs la valeur stable du gage affect5 en garantie de oes 5missions 1 Songerait-on par hasard 5 remettre en honneur les assignats ou introduire le aysthme dysastrenx des Bank- Notes de l'ltalie ou de la Grhce ? Avec de pareilles pratiques on mhnerait le pays directe- ment 5 sa ruine. On ne guyrit pas une situation yoonomique mauvaise ou dylabile avec des rerahdes empiriques qui ne feraient qu'aggra- ver la crise et faire tache d'huile. Tonte la question se ryduit actuellement 4 ce fait simple et brutal: Le besoin impyrieux d'or que nous hprouvons pour faire marcher nos entreprises, notre commerce et en dernier lien notre agriculture. Y aurait-il par hasard des moyens artificieb inconnus du public et capable* de faire coaler k nouveau ce large torrent d'or en Egypte ? Je ne le crois pas 'et n'entrevois poor ma part que deux moyens connus et yprouv5s et dont- 1'expyrience main- tes fois syculaire a dymontry le bien-fottdy : Ou nous er-'erons Tor dont nous £von* besoin par la force de notre travail et de notre Industrie ou nous l'attirerons par la confianoe de nos entreprises. Hors de 14, point de salat Veuillez agryer, Monsieur le Directeur, l'as- suranee de mes parfaits sentiments.

A Paris, le Credit Foncier Egyptien a encore avance de 5 francs 4 687. La nanque d'Athines a progresse de 1 franc 4114.

Le r4glement de l'affaire de la Cassa di Sconto,la baisse continuedu taux del'escompte lihre 4 Londres, la reprise des valeurs egyp- tiennes au Stock Exchange et 4 la Bourse de Paris, la forte hausse du coton en Amerique, tout promettait pour ce matin une bonne seance. Or, le marche n'a pas ete mauvais en realite, mais il semble avoir de$u l'attente de ceux dont la foi robuste va jusqu'4 a<lmettre la possibility d'un emballemerit irreflechi en la morte saison, aussitOt aprts une crise excep- tionnelle dont les effets se font encore pesam- ment sentir sur la place. L'amelioration n'en est. pas moins evidente. Elle est partielle et lente mais elle fiuira par se generaliser et s'ac- centuer de plus en plus d'ici 4 la reprise des affaires en automne.
En attendant, les cours des valeurs diri- geantes continuant 4 s'inscrire en progtos. Ainsi la National Bank a avance 4 19 15/16 et 1'Agricoie 4 7 15/16.
La Cassa di Sconto est restoe 4 58.Le Comptoir Financier a M moins bien tenu 4 3 ; sa part a passe de 2 4 3. La Societd Generate Egyptienne a faibli 4 235.
Le .Credit Fancier a gagne 5 francs 4 685. Lar Daira s'eat tassee 4 13 7/8-14. Les Allotments se sont alourdis 4 2.
Dee actions de capital Eaux du Caire ont fllcbi 4 112 ; les Jouisaances sont restoes 4 184.

Dans ]e groupe des valeurs hGteliires, les Nupgovjch sont revenus 4 15 3/S-1/2. Les Egnfian se sont maintenus 4 4 9/16. La part defpndateur Excelsior est tomWe 4 L.E. 0 1/2 et celle des National 4 P.E. 33.

remonteei 1 7/8. La part de fondateurEstates' est revenue 4 6. Les Salt and §oda dirt' faibli 4 17 sh. 6, les New Egyptian 4 14 sh. 4 1/2, les Constructions 4 0 3/8-7/16, les Abdy 4 0 i
et les Cotton Mills 4 3 sh.
L'aflfaire dela Cassa di Sconto edi Risparmio a re^u hier l'heureuse solution de principe que tout le monde souhaitait.

A la reprisede la stance 4 4 h. 30 de l'apres- midi, iassemble generate extraordinaire des actionnaires, cette fois Egalement constitute, a vote 4 l'unanimite l'ordre du jour pto- sentt par le conseil d'administration, savoir:

" 1. — L'assemblte generate des actionnaires decide d'autoriser le conseil 4 s'entendre avec le Syndicat des Banques, 4 la tote dnqael se trouve la National Bank of Egypt, et aux meilleures conditions qu'il Ini sera possible, afin de repreridre ses paiemerits le 5 Juillet courant et afin de rouvrir ses guichets. Et au cas oti cet emprunt venait 4 se toaliser, decider, des 4 present, la mise en liquidation amiable de la Socittt ou toute autre combi- naison utile.

2. — Dans le cas oil I'emprunt ne serait pas conclu avantleS Juillet courant, ce qni, de par la loi, obligerait le conseil 4 deposer lc bilan de la Socittt au tribunal, l'assemblte generate dtlibtre d'autoriser le conseil meme a formuler une demande pour l'obtention du btntfice du concordat ptoventif, et 4 faire les propositions de concordat qu'il croira utiles, y compris celle, s'il en ttait besoin, d'abaudon de l'actif, bien entendu jusqu'4 concurrence de 100 0/0 en capital et intorets du montant du passif, tout excellent eventual revenant aux actionnaires. "
En toponse 4 une question, M. Metaxa a dedato qn'il ne pouvait encore emettre une affirmation formelle, mais qu'il yto.it convaincu du succes des ltegociations engag^es 4 Londres.

Snr la proposition de M. Alfred Campos, l'a-ssembtee a vote des remerciements 4 la National Bank, anx autres Banques locales qni or.t aide la Cassa dans la crise, ainsi qu'4 M. Metaxa de l'Union Bank de Vienne. En outre, un vote de confiance dans le conseil d'administration, propose par M. Shaar, a ete adopto par acclamation.

Du rapport du conseil d'administration ap- prouvtfe par l'assembl4e generate ordinaire de 1'Egyptian Hotels Co., tenne avant-hier 4 Londres, il tosulte que le bdndfiee net de l'exercice clos le 30 Avril dernier a ete de £ 31,324, deduction faite des charges statutaires, amortis- sements, travaux d'agrandissement des hotels, etc. et y compris le solde ctoditeurde l'exer- cice precedent. £ 2,898 ont ete reportoes 4 nouveau.

Ainsi que nous l'avons annonce hier, les dividendes ont ete fixes 4 20 % pour les actions ordinaires et 4 5 0/o pour les actions priviiegiees. Ils sont payables depuis hier, 2 juillet courant, 4 l'AnglefEgyptian Bank au Caire.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: VOYAGES D'ETE A PRIX REDO ITS-

La Khedivial Mail Line mettra en vente 4 ses Agences d'Alexandrie, du Caire et de Port Said des billets speaiaux d'aller et retour qni pesmettront aux personnes desireuses de se rafralchir par un petit voyage en Grece, 4 Smyrne, Metelin, Constantinople ou en Syrie, de le faire 4 un taux toduit jienibmt les mois de Juillet et Aout.
Les prix seront les suivants :
Ire Clas.se 2me Glasse
L.E. L.E.
Constantinople aller et retour 10— 6.500
Smyrne et Metelin „ „ 7 — 5 —
La nourritnre pendant deux jours de qua- rantaine est comprise dans ces prix.

Des prix todnits seront accords aux passa- gers par plusieurs hotels 4 Constantinople, comme aussi au Phal4re, A thanes, etc., et si les passagers en premiere classe d^sirent rester 4 bord 5 Constantinople et retoumer par le m8me vapenr, ils auront la faculto de le faire en payant Fes. 10 par jour pour leur nour- riture.

Pour la Svrie on 8mettra Egalement des billets sp^ciaux au prix du voyage simple ponr le voyage de Taller et de retour. Le prix du voyage d'Alexandrie 4 Beyrouth et retour sera done L.E. 3 500 par personne en premiere classe et L.E. 2.600 en deuxi4me classe. CONDITIONS.
Les billets pour ces voyages ne pourront etre obtenus qu'aux Agences de la Compagnie 4 Alexandrie, Port-Said et au Caire (Bonded Stores).
Les billets seront strictement personnels et aucune autre reduction ne sera accordde.

La du toe de la validity des billets est de trois seraaine8 4 compter de Tarrivde au port de destination. Leur validity ne peut pas 6tre prolong^ sauf contre paiement de la difference entre le prix de ces billets et eelui des billets ordinaires.
Les passagers munis de ces billets n'auront pas la faculto de s'artoter dans les ports inter- utodiaires. ,
Alexandrie, le 14 juin 1907. 30586-14*-!

div.head:
RAISULI AND MACLEAN.
A TREACHEROUS CAPTURE.

div.p: Kaid Sir H. Maclean, who was negotiating with El Raisuli regarding his pardon, has been captured by El Raisuli who now exacts his own terms for ransom and pardon.
(Later). El Raisuli treacherously persuaded Sir H. Maclean to meet him personally. He was accompanied by only four men' {Reuter) Tangier, July 3.

Raisouli has captured Kaid Maclean, who came to negotiate his pardon in the name of the Sultan. Raisouli will set him at liberty after payment of a ransom and his nomination a? ttoven^>r of Tangier. (Havas)

div.head:
JAPAN AND AMERICA.
THE PACIFIC FLEET.

div.p: A semi-official statement says that Pr^ident Roosevelt is not considering the trairejfer of warships to the Pacific. Nevertheless, circumstances point to the matter having been discussed. {Reuter)
^^rermany emphatically denies having offered to America any advice concerning the disposition of her warships. {Reuter)

M.Wakatsuki of the new permanent Japanese Financial Commission here, in the course of an interview stated that Japan had no idea of considering a new foreign loan. The increase of revenue without increase of taxation proved the renewed prosperity of the coflfctry. The Japanese did not like the recent incidents in San Francisco. If they occured too often they would lead to misunderstandings, but the talk of war was utterly ridiculous. Japan fully trusted the Washington Government to act fairly. (Reuter)

A sensational advance in the price of the cotton has taken place as a result of the condition of the crops being shown as 72 % by the Bureau, which constitutes a record for July. It is asserted that the vitality of the plant is too low to raise even a moderate crop. {Reuter)

div.head:
KING EDWARD AND IRELAND.
VISIT TO DUBLIN.

div.p: Great preparations are being made for the visit of the King and Queen to the City. The decorations and illuminations will be on a scale hitherto unattempted in Ireland. (Reuter)
M. Falli&res and Prince Constantin of Greece have exchanged visits. (Havas)
The Emperor has left for Ischl, where he will pass two months.(Havas)

div.head: DENISHWAI REVIVED.
div.p: Further to our review of the 29th inst. we extract the following passages from Bernard Shaw's "John Bull's other Island" as examples of the superficialness and immoderate flippancy of his work

Not only was there of course no jury at the trial, but considerably less than no defence. Barristers of sufficient standing to make it very undesirable for them tooffend the Occupation were instructed to "defend" the prisoners. Far from defending them they paid high compliments to the Occupation as one of the choicest benefits rained by heaven on their country, and appealed for mercy for their miserable clients, whose conduct has caused the unanimous indignation of all Egyptians. "Clemency" they said "was above equity." The tribunal in delivering judgment remarked that the counsel for the defence had a full hearing, nevertheless the defence broke down completely, and all that their counsel could say on behalf of the prisoners practically amounted to an appeal to the mercy of the Court.

Now the proper defence, if put forward, would probably have convinced Lord Cromer that nothing but the burning of the village and the crucifixion of all its inhabitants could preserve the British Empire. That defence was obvious enough : the village was invaded by 5 armed foreigners who attempted for the second time to slaughter the villagers farming stock and carry it off ; in resisting an attempt to disarm them four villagers had been wounded ; the villagers had lost their tempers and knocked the invaders about; and the older men and watchmen had finally rescued the aggressors and sent them back with no worse handling than they would have got anywhere for the like misconduct.

Mr. Findlay is another interesting official correspondent of Sir Edward. Even after the trial at which it had been impossible to push the medical evidence further than to say, that the officer who died of sunstroke had been predisposed to it by the knocking about he had suffered, and by his flight under the Egyptian sun, while the officers who had remained defenceless in the hands of the villagers were in court alive and well. Mr. Findlay writes that the four hanged men were convicted of a brutal and premeditated murder and complains that the native press disregards the fact, and is being conducted with such an absolute disregard for truth as to make it evident that large sums of money have been expended. Mr Findlay is also a bit of a philosopher.The Egyptian being a fatalist, he says, does not greatly fear death, and there is therefore much to be said for flogging as a judicial punishment in Egypt. Logically, then the four lianged men ought to have been flogged instead. But Mr. Findlay does not draw that conclusion. Logic is not his strong point: he is a man of feeling, and a very nervous one at that. "I do not believe that this brutal attack on British officers had anything directly to do with political animosity."

It is however due to the insubordinate spirit which has been sedulously fostered daring the last year by unscrupulous and interested agitators. Again it is my duty to warn you of "the deplorable effect which is been produced in Egypt by the fact that metnbers of parliament have seriously called in question the unanimous sentence passed by a legally constituted court, of which the best English and the best native judges were members.

This fact will moreover supply the lever which has, up to the present been lacking to the venal agitator who are at the head of the so-called patriotic party." I find Mr. Findlay irresistible, so exquisitely does he give us the measure and flavor of officialism. A few days after the Denshawai affray some natives stoned and severely injured an irrigation inspector. Two days ago three natives knocked a soldier off his donkey and kicked him in the stomach: his injuries are serious. In the latter case theft appears to have been the motive.

My object in mentioning these instances is to show the results to be expected if once respect for the law is shaken. Should the present state of things continue, and still more, should the agitation in this country find support at home, the date is not far distant when the necessity, will arise for bringing in a press law and for considerably increasing the army ofOccupation. Just think of it! In a population of nearly 10 millions, one irrigation inspector is stoned. The Denshawai executions are then carried out to make the law respected.

The result is that three natives knock a soldier off his donkey and rob him. Thereupon Mr. Findlay, appalled at the bankruptcy of civilization, sees nothing for it now but suppression of the native newspapers and a considerable increase in the army of Occupation, and Lord Cromer writes "all I need say is that I concur generally in Mr. Findlay's remarks, and that, had I remained in Egypt, I should in every respect have adopted the same course as that which he pursued."

In any case let no Englishman who is content to leave Abdel Nebi and his twenty year old neighbour in penal servitude for life, and to plume himself on the power to do it,pretend to be fit to govern either my country or his own. The responsibility cannot be confined to the tribunal and to the demoralized officials of the Occupation.

The House of Commons had 24 hours clear notice, with the telegraph under the hand of Sir Edward Grey, to enable it to declare that England was a civilized power and would not stand these barbarous lashings and vindictive hangings. Yet Mr. Dillon, representing the Irish party, which well knows what British Occupations and Findlay loyalism mean, protested in vain.

Sir Edward on behalf of the new liberal Government (still simihering with virtuous indignation at the flogging of Chinamen and the military executions in South Africa in the forced presence of the victims under the late Imperialist Government, not only permitted and defended the Denshawai executions, but appealed to the House almost passionately not to criticise or repudiate them on the ground- how incredible it now appears—that Abdel- Nebi and Hassan Mahfouz and Darweesh and the rest were the fuglemen of a gigantic Moslem plot to rise against Christendom in the name of the prophet* and sweep Christendom out of Africa and Asia by a colossal second edition of the Indian Mutiny. That this idiotic romance, gross and ridiculous as the lies of Falstaff, should have imposed on any intelligent and politically experienced human being is strange enough—though the secret shame of revolted humanity will make cabinet ministers snatch at fantastic excuses— but what humanity will not forgive our foreign secretary for, is his failure to see that even if such a conspiracy really existed, England should have faced it and fought it bravely by honorable means, instead of wildly lashing and strangling a handful of poor peasants to scare Islam into terrified submission. Were I abject enough to giant to Sir Edward Grey, as valid, that main asset of thinking Imperially" the conviction that we are all going to be murdered, I should still suggest to him that we can at least die like gentlemen ? might 1 even be so personal as to say that the reason for giving him a social position and political opportunities that are denied to his tradesmen is that he is supposed to understand better than they that honour is worth its danger and its cost, and that life is worthless without honor? It is true that Sir John Falstaff did not think so ; but Sir John is hardly a model for Sir Edward. Yet even Sir John would have had enough gumption to see that the Denshawai panic was more dangerous to the Empire than the loss of ten pitched battles.

div.head: The Money Market.
div.p: The anticipation that Egypt would require more gold has proved correct, and this week £175,000 has left the Bank for Alexandria. With the gradual improvement in the financial position on your side, however, the fear of further heavy withdrawals becomes more remote, until the cotton demand is on us.

Gold is again being exported from America, but France has proved a very successful competitor for the bulk of this. This is due to the shrewd policy adopted by our neighbours of making advances during transit free of interest. The Bank ot England took a leaf out of the French book, and pursued this policy for a few days, and as a result managed to secure about £350,000, but on their cancelling offers to make advances, all subsequent engagement of gold was directed to Paris.

Yesterday the sum of £500,000 in Indian gold was released at the Bank and added to the general reserve. This announcement caused an easing off in the discount market, and three months' fine bills, after being 3 j, relapsed to 3$.

This week a large amount of cash has gone into the country to meet quarter-day requirements, but the net influx from abroad of £229,000 has somewhat counterbalanced this demand, with the result that the stock of coin and bullion only shows a shrinkage of £124,000. On the other hand the note circulation has expanded to the extent of £390,000, and the total reserve is down £514,000 at £24,784,000, which compares with £26,648,000 twelve months ago. The proportion to liabilities has declined 4f to 42j.
The price of bar gold is rather higher at 77/9J.

div.head: Silver.
div.p: In consequence of steady though moderate buying on behalf of the Indian Government, the silver market has remained firm. The quotation for bar silver is now 30f, after being 31.

div.head: The Stock Markets.
div.p: It is a wise saying that it is never safe to prophesy until you know, and this is especially true of the stock markets. In these panicky times the movements of shares are so easily influenced, that one can never tell what a day will bring forth. Allowing the necessity for caution, however, it is no exaggeration to say that the atmosphere of the Stock Exchange during tho past week is a good augury for the future, and the opinion we expressed last week that the end of the long lane of depression had been almost reached has been fully justified. The failure of the Cassa di Sconto was looked upon as the climax of the trouble in Egypt, and the steady improvement in prices of Egyptian securities during the past few days has been gratifying evidence of a returning spirit of confidence. When it is mentioned that National Bank shares have been as low as 16 and closed last night at 20$, it will be seen that the improvement has been real.

Those far-seeing investors who came in when prices were at rock-bottom levels are already finding themselves rewarded for their confidence in the future of these shares. As we have previously hinted "one never knows" but all the signs point to a continued improvement all-round.

Markets generally have been much firmer this week, though inclined to be rather irregular. A very good impression was created by the announcement of Mr. Asquith that the Government had no intention of bringing forward the new Transvaal loan during the present financial year. In view of the very depressed state in which the market for gilt- edged stock has been for some months, this is a wise decision.

div.head: Consols.
div.p: The market for gilt-edged stocks is now much firmer, and the liquidation in Consols has been effectively checked by the Government's announcement regarding the South African loan. Yesterday the premier security plosed an $ higher for the account at 84, 9/16, after being 11/16. To-day they show a further rise of 3/16 for cash and $ for the account, at 84 11/16.

div.head: Foreign Bonds.
div.p: The inteinational market is quiet and steady. Russians for the greater part of the week have b&en favored, but yesterday they gave way Land were again rather lower this morning. The*e has not been much doing in Japanese, which have been somewhat irregular. To-day Russian Fives have given way \ to 82 J. The Fours are unchanged at 74

div.head: Home Rails.
div.p: The improvement in the gilt-edged section has had a favourable influence on home rail way shares, which have been much in favour. Another very good point is the fact that the dividend announcements are now imminent, and it is confidently expected that in many cases these will be very satisfactory. With this prospect before them, the shares certainly seem very cheap at present prices. The railway employees have had the good sense not to force a strike at this juncture, and it is now hoped that the differences may be settled without such a misfortune occurring. Yesterday a feature was the strength of Metropolitans, which advanced 2 £ to 44 J. North Easterns and Great Easterns were also favoured, and improved $, while Midland Deferred were $ better. The market has further advanced to-day, the heavies having been very firm.

div.head: Americans.
div.p: The tone of the American market has been steady throughout, and during the latter part of the week some of the shares have received a fair amount of attention. Unions have again been a very good point Yesterday they were up to 142, and this morning were marked 2 higher. Norfolks gained f. Milwaukees and Southern Pacific $, Steels |, Missouri J, and Denver and Erie $. Steel Preferred were weak and relapsed }, while small declines were marked in Baltimore, Chesapeake, and Penns.
Americans have been active to-day, and close at the best. Unions are up 1 } and Southern pref. 4 $, to 70.

div.head: Egyptians.
div.p: Our cable of the 26th. will have prepared yon for the announcement we are now able to m^ke of a firm Egyptian market, and consider1 ably higher prices for the better class shares. Instead of the Cassa failure acting as a bear influence, the effect was just the opposite, the leading brokers here looking upon this as marking the end of the crisis. Quotations for the best shares quickly iallied, and the rise has steadily continued throughout the week.

The liquidation from Egypt seems to have ceased, and it is confidently hoped that this state of things may continue. A very large amount of shares have now been absorbed on this side, and Paris has been a iieavy buyer uf Credit Fonciere, having taken heavy amounts from Egypt

Yesterday National Bank further advanced to 20$-|, whereas a week ago we quoted them 16$-}. They are quoted to-night at 20. In nearly all cases the improvement has been marked. Agricultural Bank have gone to 8, and a very good business has been done on this basis. The preference are quoted 9§-f. Anglo-Egyptiau, which had withstood the fall in other shares fairly well, had a break to 12}-$, but recovered to 13}-$. Daira are also in demand at 14$, and Delta Preference, which on Saturday changed hands as low as 8, have very quickly regained their loss, and close 9}-J.

Delta Land and Investment after being If sellers, were in active demand yesterday, rising to 2$, Egyptian Estates are better at f, to a shade over, and Egyptian Markets at 24/-s. Salt and Soda are steady at 15/16. Union Fonciere are quoted 4}-5, and Land Bank 7—$, butrjtbere is very little business passing in these sMres.
Comptoir Financier are supposed to be 3—$, but there are no sellers about.

div.head: Mining.
div.p: There is little business passing in the Kaffir section, but prices are well maintained. The feature of interest yesterday was the announcement of the East Rand dividend, which is at the rate of 27$ per cent. (5/6 per share). The shares rose at one time to 4, buyers, but reacted to 1/16 below this figure. They leave off to-night at 4. Rand Mines are quoted 5$.
Egyptian mining shares are inactive, and prices remain about the same. Nile Valley leave off at 1 /3 and Egyptian Mines Exploration at 1/3.

L'Administration des Chemins de% Fer et Tyiygraphes de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter a la connaissance du Public qu'& partir du 5 Juillet, un bureau tylygraphique sera ouvert. k Ras el Bar, pour l'ychange des Tylygrammes en langues Europyennes et Arabe.
LTioraire de ce bureau sera de 8 h. a.m. k 1 h. p.m. et de 4 p.m. k 8 h. p.m.
Le Caire, le 28 Jum 1907. 30,559-2-2
AVIS

L'Administration des Telygraphes de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter k la connaissance du Public qu'elle dispose de 100 postes vacants k l'Ecole deTyiygraphie pour les yleves dysirant entrer au Service des Telygraphes.
Les candidats doivent remplir les conditions suivantes : ,

list.item: Avoir obtenu le certificat d'ytudes pri- maires.
Etre &gAs de 17 ans au moins et de 20 ans au plus.
Ils doivent foumir avec leurs demandes leur certificat de naissance et un certificat de bonne vie et moeurs sur papier timbry de P.T. 3.

div.p: Les demandes doivent etre adressyes k : Monsieur l'lnspecteur Gynyral
des Tyiygraphes de l'Etat,
Le Caire.

Les candidats passeront un examen pryli- minaire au Bureau Central des Tyiygraphes et la pryfyrence sera donnye k ceux qui seront a meme d'yerire trbn lisiblement et sans faute une dictye en langnes Europyennes et Arabe k raison de 20 mots par minute.

Les yttves qui, dans le courant de l'annye, passeront avec succes l'examen, seront emplo- yys comme tylygraphistes avec un traitement de L.E 5 par mois et seront classys dans le Cadre k leur tour de promotion au fur et a mesure que des vacances s'y produiront.
Les ybvfes qui, au bout d'une annye, n'au- ront pas ryussi k l'examen seront licenciys de l'Ecole.
Le Caire, le 7 Juin 1907. 30571-2-2

div.head: Egyptian State Railways and Telegraph
div.p: NOTICE.

The Administration has the honour to inform the Public that tenders will be received up to noon on the 3rd October 1907 for the supply of timber during the year 1908 accordance with the conditions which may be obtained, against payment of 100 miUiemes, at the Administration's General Stores at Boulac and at the Office of the Inspector of Stores at Gabbary (Alexandria).

Tenderers must lodge, as a provisional deposit the sum of L.E. 100. After acceptance of his tender, he will lodge a final guarantee by incieasing the provisional deposit, so as to make up an amount equalling 10 % of his accepted offer.

Tenders must be accompanied by a stamped paper of 30 millifemes and be addressed by registered post to "General Manager, Egyptian State Railways, Cairo" and in two envelopes, the inner bearing the following inscription :—
"Tender for timber supply".
The Administration is not bound to' accept the lowest or any tender, and reserves to itself the right of dividing the contract. 30560-2-2
